channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Jonas Kaufmann, Nina Stemme Named Best Singers at Opera Awards
item.description: The Opera Awards, in their first year, honored achievement during 2012 and were determined by a 10-person jury, following nominations from the public.
item.dc:creator: By GEORGE LOOMIS

item.title: India Ink: When ‘Love Marriage’ Needs a Little Help
item.description: Forward-looking Indian parents, who agree not to force children into arranged marriages, push kids to wed in other ways.
item.category: Life and Love in the New Bangalore
item.dc:creator: By SARITHA RAI
item.media:description: Floh members interacting at an event in Bangalore, Karnataka, on March 31, 2012.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 23
item.description: Pollution radically changes childhood in China; Germany fines Google; a former soccer champion faces prison; the deaths of a Woodstock musician and a Cuban cinema giant.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at the International School of Beijing playing in one of two domes with air-filtration systems for when smog is severe.

item.title: Visit to Japanese War Shrine Draws Anger
item.description: South Korea and China objected Monday after Japanese cabinet ministers visited a controversial war shrine.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: China’s Criticism of U.S. on Human Rights Draws Support (and Mockery)
item.description: Many Chinese netizens were unimpressed by a state report criticizing the U.S. human rights situation, which focused largely on gun violence.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A screengrab from the Sina Weibo account of Xinhua, the state-run news agency, showing an annoyed Uncle Sam surrounded by points detailing China's criticisms of human rights in the United States. The main criticism is gun violence.

item.title: Bayern President Faces Prison in Tax Evasion Case
item.description: Uli Hoeness, a former soccer champion, faces up to 10 years in prison after he acknowledged that he kept a secret bank account to evade taxes.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Uli Hoeness turned himself in to prosecutors for keeping a secret account to evade taxes.

item.title: Japanese and Chinese Boats Converge on Contested Islands
item.description: Beijing and Tokyo sent vessels to monitor a flotilla of boats carrying Japanese nationalists that sailed near islands in the East China Sea that both nations claim as their own.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: 2 Accused in Canada of Plot to Derail Train
item.description: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police said they arrested two foreign nationals on Monday, but offered few details of a plot they linked to “Al Qaeda elements” in Iran.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Interim Government Puts Off Musharraf Charges
item.description: Pakistan’s caretaker government declined on Monday to bring treason charges against Pervez Musharraf, a former military leader, saying it was beyond its mandate.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Foreigners Among Civilians Feared Held by Taliban
item.description: Eight Turkish engineers and at least one Russian were among those taken hostage after surviving a forced landing in eastern Afghanistan, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Prison for Preachers
item.description: Chinese authorities have sentenced to prison seven underground church leaders arrested last April and charged with belonging to an illegal cult, according to a Christian rights group.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Nicaragua: U.S. Fugitive Captured
item.description: The police in Nicaragua have detained Eric Justin Toth, who was one of the F.B.I.’s 10 most-wanted fugitives.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Court Hears Case on Attaching Condition to Federal Grant
item.description: The Supreme Court heard arguments about whether groups receiving federal money to combat AIDS abroad may be required to adopt policies opposing prostitution.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM LIPTAK
item.media:description: The Supreme Court heard arguments about whether groups fighting AIDS abroad should adopt an anti-prostitution policy.

item.title: John Kerry to Meet With Afghan and Pakistani Leaders
item.description: The meeting with Secretary of State John Kerry in Belgium will try to foster cooperation over the stalled reconciliation process with the Taliban and other issues.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Two Syrian Archbishops Abducted in Northern Syria
item.description: The abductees, the Syriac Orthodox and the Greek Orthodox archbishops of Aleppo, were thought to be the most senior clerics seized in the Syrian civil war.
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Free Syrian Army fighters in Aleppo, the nation’s largest city. Two archbishops were abducted on Monday near the city.

item.title: Alfredo Guevara Valdés, Steward of Cuban Cinema and Castro Ally, Dies at 87
item.description: Mr. Guevara was a Marxist intellectual and ally of Fidel Castro’s who presided over Cuba’s powerful state-financed film industry for much of the Castro era.
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: U.S. and China Hold Military Talks, With Cybersecurity a Focus
item.description: A Chinese general said he pledged to work with America on cybersecurity because the consequences of a major attack might be “as serious as a nuclear bomb.”
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: The Joint Chiefs of Staff chairman, Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, left, and Gen. Fang Fenghui of China on Monday in Beijing.

item.title: Vlado Jankovic Is Star for Panionios in Greece
item.description: Vlado Jankovic, the son of a beloved player paralyzed 20 years ago, has had a breakthrough season with his father’s former club. But he may soon leave the team.
item.dc:creator: By KEN MAGUIRE
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vlado Jankovic under the banner of his father, Boban, who severely damaged his spinal cord while playing for Panionios. His father died in 2006. Jankovic is being scouted by big-budget European teams.

item.title: Turkey Criticizes Kerry Over Request to Delay Gaza Trip
item.description: A spokesman for Turkey’s government said it had been arrogant of Secretary of State John Kerry to suggest that Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan postpone a trip to the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Napolitano Sworn In to Second Term in Italy
item.description: President Giorgio Napolitano, sworn in on Monday, called on bickering political parties to find common ground for the good of the nation.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: In France, Opposition to Same-Sex Marriage Bill Grows
item.description: Polls show a majority of the French favor equal rights for same-sex couples, but critics of President François Hollande have used protests against the bill as a way to attack him.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: Protesters faced off against riot police officers on Sunday after a demonstration in Paris, where tens of thousands of opponents of a same-sex marriage bill gathered.

item.title: Pollution Is Radically Changing Childhood in China’s Cities
item.description: High levels of deadly pollutants in Beijing and other cities have led parents to alter their children’s day-to-day activities drastically, and some plan to leave the country.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wu Xiaotian, 3, who has breathing problems, played a game while wearing a mask this month at his home in Beijing, China.

item.title: Memo from Europe: Europe’s Shrinking Military Budgets Scrutinized
item.description: The financial crisis is seen taking a toll on individual countries’ defense capabilities as well as their role in helping the United States finance NATO.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Armorers on the French aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle on April 13 prepared a fighter jet for a mission over Libya.

item.title: In Nigeria, Clash With Militants Kills Scores
item.description: The battle with Boko Haram insurgents highlighted the brutal tactics of Nigerian soldiers in the nearly four-year uprising.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: WORLD: Rage After Child Rape in India
item.description: Protesters besieged police headquarters in New Delhi, outraged by reports of the rape and torture of a 5-year-old girl.
